title: Amish people do get vaccinated - Full Fact
description: False social media claims link Amish lifestyles to the absence of diseases. Amish people do use vaccines and GMOs, and they do also have conditions like autism and SIDS.
cleaned_text: What was claimed The Amish are an unvaccinated population. Our verdict Vaccine uptake in Amish communities may be lower than the US national average, but significant numbers do vaccinate their children for some diseases. The Amish are an unvaccinated population. Vaccine uptake in Amish communities may be lower than the US national average, but significant numbers do vaccinate their children for some diseases. The Amish do not use GMO crops. Significant numbers of Amish farmers use GMO seeds. There is no autism or sudden infant death syndrome in Amish communities. This is not true. Both have been reported. The Amish are the healthiest people in the Western world. No vaxx, no masks, no GMO, no TV No autism, no myocarditis, no SIDS, no SADS, no ADHD The founder and leader of the Heritage Party, David Kurten, made several false claims about the health of Amish people in a [widely shared tweet](https://twitter.com/davidkurten/status/1680504723835592705) that has been viewed over 3.5 million times. Many Amish people are vaccinated against various diseases. Some also use GMO (genetically modified) seeds. Similar claims about the Amish have previously been fact checked by the [Associated Press](https://apnews.com/article/fact-check-amish-covid-vaccines-cancer-diabetes-autism-356029928165). Full Fact has contacted David Kurten but no response has been received as of the time of writing. Myocarditis, sudden infant/adult death syndrome (SIDS and SADS) are often involved in [false](/health/instagram-myocarditis-children/) [claims](/health/covid-vaccine-myocarditis-false/) [related](/health/sads-covid-genocide/) to [vaccines](/online/Sids-vaccines/). Vaccine misinformation can harm health, as people may make decisions based on [false claims](/health/vaccines/). Honesty in public debate matters You can help us take action - and get our regular free email The [Amish are Christian religious communities](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Amish) with settlements in the US and Canada. They generally live "traditional" farming lifestyles, and they do indeed generally [reject television](https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/americanexperience/features/amish-who-is-amish/#:~:text=many%20subgroups%2C%20the-,vast%20majority,-of%20Old%20Order). However, the claim that they use "no GMO" seems to be false. For example, [a 2022 study](https://ideaexchange.uakron.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1230&context=amishstudies#page=8) of 76 Amish corn farms found that just under 40% used GMO seeds in 2019, down from almost half of them in 2011. The Amish historically have also used vaccines. Katrine Wallace, an epidemiologist at the University of Illinois at Chicago's School of Public Health, previously [told the Associated Press](https://apnews.com/article/fact-check-amish-covid-vaccines-cancer-diabetes-autism-356029928165#:~:text=%E2%80%9CThey%20do%20vaccinate%20at%20a%20lower%20rate%20than%20the%20general%20population%2C%20but%20they%20are%20far%20from%20an%20%E2%80%98unvaccinated%E2%80%99%20population%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.) that "They do vaccinate at a lower rate than the general population, but they are far from an 'unvaccinated' population". A [2011 study](https://publications.aap.org/pediatrics/article-abstract/128/1/79/30323/Underimmunization-in-Ohio-s-Amish-Parental-Fears?redirectedFrom=fulltext) of Amish parents in Ohio found that 85% of those surveyed accepted some vaccines for their children. A [2021 study](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0264410X21000268?via=ihub) in the same settlement found vaccine acceptance had decreased, with 41% of respondents having vaccinated their children for some diseases. We have not been able to find data showing what proportion of the total Amish population have been vaccinated at some point. We have not been able to find data showing the prevalence of autism in Amish people, but the evidence we have suggests that it does occur. As described in a [community note](https://twitter.com/i/birdwatch/n/1680525281184866305) attached to the tweet, a [2010 study](https://imfar.confex.com/imfar/2010/webprogram/Paper7336.html) in Holmes County and a settlement in Indiana found an autism rate of 1 in 271 children—lower than the national rate at the time, but not zero. We have not been able to find reliable data on the rates of ADHD, myocarditis and SADS among the Amish. However, SIDS sadly does sometimes occur. A [report in 2004](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC511011/#:~:text=Over%20two%20generations) documented 21 cases in nine Amish families and received [wide](https://www.theguardian.com/science/2004/jul/20/health.medicineandhealth) [press](https://www.irishtimes.com/news/amish-may-hold-sids-secret-1.1152188) [coverage](https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB109026849191867622). Featured image courtesy of [TheCadExpert](https://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Lancaster_County_Amish_03.jpg) Full Fact fights for good, reliable information in the media, online, and in politics.
